Then the sun god king, together with innumerable hundreds of thousands of celestial beings, came to where the Buddha was, bowed their heads at his feet, and then stood to one side. They addressed the Buddha, saying:
By what practices does the sun god king illuminate the four continents?
For what reasons does the moon illuminate the night and dispel darkness?
The Buddha told the sun god king:
There are four kinds of practices by which one becomes the sun god king.
What are the four?

Always delighting in giving, cultivating the body, being careful in conduct, upholding the precepts without transgression, and also offering lamps in Buddhist temples, or planting the merit of light for one's parents, Å›ramaá¹‡as, and those who have attained the Way;
these are the four.
The Buddha then spoke a verse, saying:
Always delighting in giving, upholding the precepts without transgression;
If one offers lamps in a Buddha temple, or in front of one's parents,
If one delights in the true canon of the Buddha, and does not slander the Dharma of the scriptures;
If one respects Å›ramaá¹‡as and practitioners, one will attain the status of the sun through this.
The body emits a thousand lights, universally illuminating the four continents;
In all the dark places, there is none that is not illuminated by its radiance.
The Buddha told the Sun King:
There are also ten things for becoming the sun god.
What are the ten?

Not killing, stealing, or engaging in sexual misconduct with the body; not engaging in divisive speech, harsh speech, false speech, or frivolous speech with the mouth; and not harboring ill-will, envy, or ignorance with the mind;
These are the ten.
The Buddha then spoke a verse, saying:
Respectfully restraining oneself, not killing, stealing, or engaging in sexual misconduct;
Not engaging in divisive speech or harsh speech, false speech or frivolous speech;
The mind not harboring jealousy, and free from the poisons of anger and hatred;
Free from the sixty-two views, the sun shines in the four directions.
The Buddha told King SÅ«rya:
There are four more things by which one can become a moon king.
What are the four?
Generosity to the poor and destitute, upholding the five precepts, revering the Three Jewels, and offering lamps in temples for one's father, teachers, and the Sangha;
These are the four.
The Buddha then spoke a verse:
Generosity to the poor and destitute, always upholding the five precepts;
Offering lamps in the Buddha's temples, respectfully serving the Three Jewels.
Keeping the mind focused on wholesome thoughts, eliminating the many evils of the world;
Guarding one's body, speech, and mind, one attains the moonlight illuminating the darkness.
At that time, King SÅ«rya said to the Buddha:

I only wish that the Great Sage would deign to come to my palace for a light meal, so that all the guides and spirits in the sky may receive great blessings, hear the profound and wonderful Dharma, and all give rise to the intention to attain enlightenment, with immeasurable salvation.
At that time, the Buddha remained silent, accepting the invitation.

King SÅ«rya, seeing that the Buddha had already agreed to the invitation, circumambulated the Buddha three times and suddenly returned to the palace. He prepared a hundred kinds of food and various delicacies, and adorned the beds and mats with fresh and clean decorations. He laid out a seat for the Buddha, four thousand li high.
Then, King SÅ«rya stood in the palace, repeatedly inviting the Buddha from afar with bowed head and bated breath, praising him in verse, saying:
Generously giving to all, without stinginess,
Not hoping for repayment, attaining Buddhahood to liberate the ten directions.
Wisdom like empty space, transforming without obstruction,
All receive grace, when the time comes, please deign to come.
With a compassionate mind, benefiting sentient beings, never harming,
Feeling sorrow for those who are not yet liberated, bestowing the Dharma treasure to teach.
The majestic spirit illuminates the multitude, rescuing and liberating the poor and destitute,
With the seven great treasures, it is time to humbly request the honored one to come.
Seeing sentient beings confused, suffering in the five realms,
Always bestowing great kindness, comforting and encouraging all fears.
Opening and transforming with the teachings, guiding those who are lacking,
Cultivating the wisdom of emptiness, it is time to humbly request the honored one to come.
Its light surpasses the sun and moon, its majestic virtue surpasses Mount Sumeru;
Its wisdom surpasses space, incomparable to anything else.
The sun and moon illuminate the darkness, only able to bring forth myriad things;
The Buddha illuminates the people of the five realms, causing them all to attain the five eyes.
Space can still be measured, the number of drops in the ocean can be known;
Mount Sumeru and the lands of the ten directions can also have their weight known.
The wisdom and sageliness of the TathÄgata, its merit and virtue are vast and lofty;
Infinitely surpassing them all, it is time to humbly request the honored one to come.
At that time, the World-Honored One told the great assembly:
The time has come, all of you be ready to go to King SÅ«rya's invitation.
They all accepted the instruction.
The Buddha and the great assembly rose into the sky and arrived at King SÅ«rya's palace, sitting on the lion's seat.

When the assembly had finished sitting, the queen, prince, and heavenly retinue bowed to the ground, and with utmost sincerity made offerings to the World-Honored One, personally serving a hundred kinds of delicacies. After the meal, they washed up, took a low seat, and sat in front of the Buddha, respectfully listening to the Dharma.
The Buddha told King SÅ«rya:

All the forms and appearances received in the three realms come from the mind. The mind is formless but creates, following one's actions to establish the body. Whether noble or humble, rich or poor, all return to impermanence, like a bubble that rises for a moment and then collapses. All that exists in the world is like this!
You should believe that the Way and virtue are true and reliable, and the rest cannot be relied upon. Abandon various practices and practice the Dharma.
What is meant by practicing the Dharma?
The practice of non-arising eliminates all that is born, the practice of true reality is exceptionally abiding, the practice of entering the Way
is without forgetfulness, the practice of giving is without stinginess or expectation, the practice of upholding precepts
is universally attaining all wishes, the practice of patience is not confusing the multitude, the practice of vigor is never
wavering, the practice of meditation is always penetrating with mental activity, the practice of wisdom is seeing with the eyes of sages,
the practice of loving-kindness is enduring all suffering, the practice of compassion is the same mind towards sentient beings, the practice of joy
is teaching and transforming with the Dharma, the practice of guarding is comforting all, the practice of spiritual powers
is penetrating with the six supernormal knowledges, the practice of emptiness is the mind of non-hatred or harm, the practice of elimination is liberating
all the multitude, the practice of the four kinds of kindness is gathering and saving people, the practice of extensive learning is from receiving and upholding
attaining the Way, the practice of non-arising is contemplating naturalness, the practice of the factors of the Way is not attaining conditioned things,
The practice of non-arising has no retribution of sin or merit. The practice of dependent origination clearly knows that ignorance is inexhaustible.
The practice of various toils understands the naturalness of people and things. The practice of various dharmas realizes the wisdom of seeing emptiness.
Attaining equal enlightenment, the practice of subduing demons cannot be shaken. Although dwelling in the field of the three realms,
one does not fall. The practice of a lion is excellently victorious and fearless. The practice of power and fearlessness is fearless in all directions.
The practice of the three insights is unobstructed. In the field of one-pointed awareness, great wisdom is universally possessed. The practice of teaching all is all-pervading.
Transforming the sixty-two views, the practice of liberation saves the multitude of nets. The ninety-six paths teach entering the one path.
Thus, O King!

If bodhisattvas practice in accordance with this, they will follow the path. Having followed the path, they will follow great compassion. Having followed great compassion, they will follow the great armor. Having followed the great armor, they will roar the lion's roar. Having roared the lion's roar, they will follow the transformation of illusions. Having followed the transformation of illusions, they will enter the five destinies. Having followed the five destinies, they will enter according to the time. Having entered according to the time, there is nothing that is not transformed. Having been in the transformations, there is no going and no coming.
Liberating without liberating, purifying without purifying, illuminating without illuminating, awakening without awakening, this is true enlightenment.
The Buddha told King SÅ«rya:

If you wish to understand the affairs of the past, present, and future, and the equality of the Dharma bodies of the buddhas of the ten directions, you should always believe and enjoy the discrimination of this meaning;

If you wish to know the rise of the twelve links of dependent origination in birth and death, the calamities of the three destinies, and the five hindrances that cover, you should understand this meaning and believe in and practice it;

If one wishes to understand the essentials of the twelve divisions of the scriptures, to open the teaching of the three insights and transcend the three liberations to reach the wisdom of the three insights, one should understand this meaning.
Just as towns, villages, and hamlets, and the grasses, trees, medicinal herbs, and fruit trees of the hundred grains, all grow from the earth.
The bodhisattva enters this wisdom and there is nothing that is not transformed, all are established up to the unsurpassed true path, and the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas all rely on it.

When the Buddha spoke this, the heavenly king of the sun, the queen, the prince, the retinue, and the devas, their minds naturally all attained the forbearance of the unarisen [dharmas], and ten koá¹­is of heavenly beings gave rise to the intention for unsurpassed true enlightenment.
At that time, the World-Honored One immediately rose from his seat and stood in the sky, surrounded by countless hundreds of thousands of retinue, and spoke in verse:
The devas and humans do not understand, coming from the past is difficult to measure;
Confused in the five destinies, like a fish caught on a hook.
The three realms are like an illusion, fleeting and nowhere to be seen;
The living do not realize it themselves, being controlled by their own consciousness.
Falling into the four inverted views, they are truly pitiable;
They themselves think their bodies are permanent, not believing in the true Way.
Everything arises from emptiness, yet they turn away from hearing about the wisdom of emptiness;
It is like a person who is born from their parents, yet is not filial to them.
A person who transforms into a tiger does not realize they were once human;
They then return to harm their family, not distinguishing between relatives and strangers.
People originally arise from emptiness, hating emptiness is like this!
Confused and disordered by the aggregates and sense-fields, like a drunkard running around naked.
A person who transforms into a human then recognizes their family and relatives;
Having distinguished their original non-existence, they then understand all is empty.
Emptiness does not think of emptiness, emptiness also does not see emptiness;
Having already reached non-arising, one is then able to understand spontaneity.
If one wishes to seek the bodhisattva practice, to liberate the various kinds of sentient beings;
One should understand that all dharmas are spontaneous, like illusions and transformations.
Having discriminated this wisdom,
One should not find it difficult to turn around;
Then deeply enter the subtle, and with skillful wisdom liberate people.

When the Buddha spoke this, countless billions of gods and spirits in the sky all gave rise to the intention of unsurpassed, true, and equal enlightenment. Incalculable bodhisattvas attained the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas. The Buddha returned to the Jeta Grove in AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada's Park in ÅšrÄvastÄ«.

At that time, there was a great elder in the city named Jie Faduo - he had made offerings to countless hundreds of thousands of past buddhas, planted immeasurable roots of virtue, bowed to and made offerings to countless buddhas, received the Dharma teachings, and his resolve for the unsurpassed true path was irreversible. He had attained the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas and emerged from wisdom. The skillful means by which he saved others were beyond measure. Together with his retinue, he came to where the Buddha was, bowed his head, sat to one side, put his palms together, and said to the Buddha:
What merits are attained by making offerings to the World-Honored One?
The Buddha told the elder:
Those who scatter flowers to the Buddha will be well-proportioned and handsome in every life, with clothing and food coming naturally.
Those who burn incense will have a fragrant and pure body and their fame and virtue will be widely known.
Those who light lamps will have the bright wisdom of the heavenly eye and will not dwell in darkness.
Those who offer banners and flags will enjoy wealth and have limitless treasures wherever they are.
Those who offer canopies of fine silk will obtain houses and be sheltered and not exposed to the elements.
Those who provide music, entertainment, and pleasure to Buddha stupas and temples will attain the heavenly ear that can hear far away;
Those who give shoes and carriages will attain lightness and the ability to fly;
Those who single-mindedly face the Buddha will know their past lives;
Those who compassionately observe sentient beings will know the minds of all;
Those who give the Dharma will attain the extinction of all defilements;
Those who give food will always encounter Dharma assemblies;
Those who give clothing will attain the thirty-two marks and eighty minor marks.
After my nirvana, those who make offerings to images and relics will all have merits like this!
Gradually following the Dharma, they will attain liberation from the path of non-action.
The Elder Expounder of the Dharma again said to the Buddha:
Are there offerings surpassing these flowers, incense, banners, canopies, music, shoes, carriages, food, and clothing?
The Buddha said:
There are.
He further asked:
What are they?
The Buddha said:

To give rise to the bodhisattva mind and have compassion for all, wishing to deliver them from the sufferings of birth and death,ğŸ”½with great kindness and great compassion, not wearying of birth and death, seeking the profound secrets of the three treasuries of dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s, the profound and immeasurable wisdom of the boundless,
leveling out the three evil paths and guiding with the three jewels, discerning emptiness,

signlessness, and wishlessness, transcending the three gates of liberation and attaining the wisdom of the three insights, seeing the fundamental basis of people and the place of original non-existence,
observing all dharmas as also without coming or going, the six sense faculties naturally like
bubbles on water, the four truths without truth like a mirage, understanding the original non-existence and then it becomes the right
truth, with kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity, giving the Dharma, loving sentient beings, encouraging the multitude,
equally benefiting all, with the six pÄramitÄs and skillful means, following and transforming without disliking
birth and death;

It is like a flying bird flying happily in the sky, like a garden of flowers and fruits, a flowing spring and a pavilion for play, not going against the true and wonderful ocean of the great sage, not fearing the four demons, subduing the sixty-two views of the multitude of heterodoxies, transforming and inspiring the ninety-six kinds of deluded paths, abandoning the practices of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, knowing that there is no self, no person, no life, and no soul, and following the correct and true unsurpassed great way. This offering is the most supreme.
Contemplate one's own body as merely an illusion, and the twelve links of dependent origination are fundamentally without a beginning.
Why is it so?
Originally there is no delusion, but it arises due to conditions. From delusion comes action;
from action comes consciousness;
from consciousness comes name and form;
from name and form come the six sense bases;
from the six sense bases comes contact;ğŸ”½from contact comes feeling;
from feeling comes craving;ğŸ”½from craving comes grasping;
from grasping comes becoming;ğŸ”½from becoming comes birth;
from birth comes death;
From death comes sorrow;
From sorrow comes grief, lamentation, distress, and vexation.

If one understands that the fundamental nature is originally non-existent, then there is no more delusion, and how could there be the suffering of birth, old age, sickness, and death, or the suffering of sorrow and lamentation?
It will forever be non-existent.

All conditions are completely eliminated, not dwelling in the three realms, not delighting in nirvana, no thought of the great way, no thought of the small way, wandering in birth, old age, and death.
It is like the sun and moon not emerging or entering, yet for the people of the world there is emergence and entry.
The bodhisattvas are like this!

They transform and teach all beings, manifesting birth in the three realms, expounding the teachings of the three vehicles, and then manifesting nirvana. For all people they show birth and cessation, but in the bodhisattva Dharma there is no birth or cessation.
This offering is the most supreme, the most honored, the most exalted, the ultimate, and bottomless offering.

When the Buddha spoke this, a hundred thousand gods and humans all gave rise to the intention for unsurpassed, true, and proper enlightenment. The Elder Understanding Dharma and his relatives all attained the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas.
Then the Bodhisattva Taming the Mind addressed the Buddha, saying:
What is meant by taming?
What is meant by a treasure?
The Buddha said:
If one is scolded, beaten, cursed, or slandered, the mind remains unchanged.
If one is humiliated, slighted, insulted, or spat upon, the mind remains unchanged.
If one is praised, respected, or proclaimed to have merit, the mind remains unchanged.
If one bows, pays homage, kneels, or shows reverence, the mind remains unchanged.
Even if one is tempted with the pleasures of heavenly blessings, the turning of the wheel, or the love of a noble one, the mind remains unchanged.
Even if one is threatened with the calamities and terrors of the hells, hungry ghosts, or animals, the mind remains unchanged.
Knowing that life is impermanent, suffering, empty, and not a self, one shows this to others, and the mind remains unchanged.
If one uses the methods of the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas to guide and inspire them, their minds remain unchanged;
Even if one uses the wisdom of emptiness and the great vehicle of the bodhisattvas to transform them, their minds remain unchanged. This is called discipline.
What is meant by 'treasure'?
The Buddha said:
Giving rise to the bodhisattva mind and wishing to liberate all beings - this is a treasure;
Respecting the Buddha and not following non-Buddhist paths - this is a treasure;
Understanding the sÅ«tras, following the teachings, and not going against the great transformation - this is a treasure;
Being humble and respectful towards the saá¹…gha and the noble assembly - this is a treasure;
Generously giving to all without any expectation of reward - this is a treasure;
Upholding the precepts and observing the prohibitions while giving rise to the bodhisattva vow - this is a treasure;
The power of patience and forbearance, subduing the mind and not being disturbed - this is a treasure;
Diligent and earnest in cultivating the path and striving for the fundamental - this is a treasure;
Single-mindedly practicing concentration, correct and not deluded - this is a treasure;
Wisdom is profound and subtle, not falling into the six deteriorations, this is a treasure;
Skillful means are each appropriate, this is a treasure;
Compassion is vast and the intention is not petty, this is a treasure;
Always harboring pity and sympathy for those in danger and distress, this is a treasure;
Tranquility, joy, and equanimity, neither elated nor depressed, this is a treasure;
Protecting all without fail to rescue and liberate, this is a treasure;
Giving the Dharma, not worldly or secular, this is a treasure;
Nurturing beings without attachment to love or hatred, this is a treasure;
Striving to bring lasting benefit without any loss or waste, this is a treasure;
Equally benefiting all without biased intentions, this is a treasure;ğŸ”½Always being humble and unassuming, never arrogant or indulgent, this is a treasure;
If scolded, not harboring resentment, this is a treasure;
If beaten, considering it as if one had no body, this is a treasure;
If one responds with kindness and compassion to anger and harm, this is a treasure;
If one does not think of the evil of others, this is a treasure;
If one understands that the body is not the self and does not cling to an ego, this is a treasure;
If one understands all suffering and does not indulge in pleasure, this is a treasure;
If one does not possess things and is not deluded by form, this is a treasure;
If one abandons the practices of the Å›rÄvakas and does not become a pratyekabuddha, this is a treasure;
If one still cultivates spiritual transformation in the five and six, this is a treasure;
If one does not fall into wrong views by rejecting the sixty-two views, this is a treasure;
If one does not dwell in nirvÄá¹‡a and does not endanger saá¹ƒsÄra, this is a treasure;
If one always uses the great Dharma to teach and transform those who have not heard it, this is a treasure;
If one shows the Dharma bridge to all people and rescues them from various calamities, this is a treasure;
If one understands that the three realms are empty and everything is natural, this is a treasure.
Bodhisattva Lotus Purity said to the Buddha:
What is meant by a bodhisattva attaining pure conduct?
The World-Honored One said:
Not being tainted by love and desire, this is purity;
Always keeping the mind bright and not harboring anger, this is purity;
Not being stained or obstructed by the dust of the three realms, this is purity;ğŸ”½Not hoping for nirvana and not enduring birth and death, this is purity;
Not calculating the beginning and end, coming and going without action, this is purity;
Always practicing great kindness and not abandoning great compassion, this is purity;
Having no thought of the great way and seeking no small way, this is purity.
Bodhisattva Guangying addressed the Buddha, saying:
For what reasons does a bodhisattva's radiance shine everywhere?
The Buddha said:

In the temples of the Buddha's light, learning and wisdom are vast and inexhaustible. Revealing the path of enlightenment and illuminating true and false, following the twelve divisions of the scriptures, crossing the ocean of existence with the six bonds, always aspiring to the Mahayana, dispelling the afflictions of the masses and reaching subtle wisdom - this is the bodhisattva's radiance illuminating everywhere.
The Bodhisattva Jieba said to the Buddha:
Why are the bodhisattvas liberated from all bonds?
The Buddha said:

Understanding the emptiness of the three realms, without attachment to the past, present, and future, the three defilements are then removed. Distinguishing the emptiness of form, feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness is also like this!
All are originally non-existent, neither attached to nor severed. Not seeking even a single thing, and not abandoning anything, this is the bodhisattva's liberation from all bonds.
The Bodhisattva Bao Shi said to the Buddha:
What is considered a treasure?
What is considered a stone?
The World-Honored One said:

Taking refuge in the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹…gha, not engaging in non-Dharma, abandoning the ninety-six kinds of heterodox paths, not aspiring to the Å›rÄvaka or pratyekabuddha [vehicles], always aiming for the Great Way, with great compassion saving sentient beings from the delusions of the five paths - this is a treasure.
Seeing the twelve links of dependent origination as deluded and mistaken, not recognizing the wisdom of the emptiness of the great Dharma - this is a stone.
Bodhisattva En Shi asked the Buddha:
What is meant by bodhisattvas bestowing grace upon sentient beings?
The Buddha said:

Those who have not yet given rise to the intention are all caused to give rise to it, those who have regressed are caused not to regress, in all that is born there is nothing that arises, those who are not yet complete reach the stage of one life to buddhahood - this is what it means for bodhisattvas to bestow grace upon all.
Bodhisattva Di Tian asked the Buddha:
What is meant by bodhisattvas being able to transform all gods?
The Buddha said:
In the desire realm, manifesting that desires are impermanent, like a person's dream, demonstrating pure conduct;
In the form realm, they manifest the practices of great loving-kindness bodhisattvas;

In the formless realm, they manifest the profound and wondrous Dharma, without relying on anything, not relying on the desire realm, not relying on the form realm, not relying on the formless realm, not relying on the Lesser Vehicle, and not relying on the Great Way.
This is how bodhisattvas are able to transform the devas.
The bodhisattva Water Deva addressed the Buddha, saying:
What is meant by bodhisattvas understanding fundamental purity?
The World-Honored One said:
Bodhisattvas understand that all dharmas are like illusions and transformations, all originally non-existent.
It is like water, which originally has no impurities.
Why is this so?
Because water, when still, is clear as it was before.
By understanding the originally non-existent, one then attains the Dharma body.
The bodhisattva Great Guide addressed the Buddha, saying:
What is meant by bodhisattvas being guides for all?
The World-Honored One said:

Seeing those who are stingy and greedy, guide them to give in charity; those who are negligent, guide them to guard their precepts; those who are angry, guide them to be patient; those who are lazy, guide them to be diligent; those whose minds are scattered, guide them to be single-minded; those who are ignorant, guide them to have wisdom; those who do not have the mind of the Way, guide them to the Great Vehicle. This is the bodhisattva being a guide for all.
The Bodhisattva Dragon Giver said to the Buddha:
What is meant by the bodhisattva not sparing his body and life?
The World-Honored One said:

The bodhisattva observes that all that exists is impermanent, suffering, empty, and not a self. I do not have a body, and the body is not mine. All is like a shadow, appearing due to form. Birth and death are like this, formed from the mind.

Understanding that all is empty, with nothing to seek, the self is naturally so. The self being naturally so, birth and death are naturally so. Birth and death being naturally so, nirvana is naturally so. Nirvana being naturally so, the Great Way is naturally so. This is the bodhisattva not sparing his body and life.
At that time, Brahma Heaven said to the Buddha:

How great is the Dharma! It is truly difficult to encounter. From countless eons, accumulating practices and virtues, one may faintly hear the sound. Fortunately, encountering the Great Sage, one gets to hear this Dharma.

Making offerings to the bodhisattva's true canon, the essential and wondrous teachings, the profound meaning, having already respectfully listened to and understood this Dharma, therefore causing that person to practice in accordance with the six praises. Hearing this sutra is already seeing the Buddha with one's own eyes!

Listening to the wondrous wisdom and making offerings to the holy assembly, crossing the heavenly path and pulling out from the three paths, causing them to give rise to the intention of the unsurpassed true path, embodying the three liberations without neglecting the three penetrations, although not yet reaching the path, their virtue gradually increases.

Like the beginning of the moon, like the fearless and self-reliant cub of a lion, all the devas, dragons, and spirits will guard and protect them, and the various demons and evil ones will naturally submit. In all the states, cities, counties, countries, and villages, there is none that does not respect and honor them. Entering and leaving in accordance with the season, the majestic spiritual transformations of the buddhas of the ten directions will aid and protect them.
At that time, the Four Heavenly Kings said to the Buddha:
Excellent and very good! The great sage's vast grace manifests in the turbid world, enabling us to behold the peaceful abode and encounter this wonderful transformation.

The pure wisdom of the bodhisattvas is like the god among gods. If someone sets out to enter the great ocean and obtains the wish-fulfilling jewel for all wishes, how could the joy of that person be measured?

We are like this. We have come to this great assembly to gaze upon the compassionate grace, listen to and receive the sweet dew of the bodhisattvas' sublime principles, just as entering the great ocean and obtaining this precious jewel. We should proclaim and reveal it to our like-minded companions, practicing the bodhisattva's conduct;
The heavenly beings who have never had faith and joy, relying on the class of those who accumulate blessings, should be caused to be greatly illuminated;
Like opening the heart to receive and study, those who have faith and joy should be caused to be twice as firm in their progress without turning back.
The Buddha said:
Excellent, O Four Heavenly Kings!
It is truly as you have said. This great Dharma is difficult to see and hear. If one stumbles once, one will be forever separated from the Dharma.
It is difficult to encounter even in a thousand koá¹­is of kalpas.
It is like a needle falling into the great ocean, turning over and seeking it, can it be easily found?
The Four Heavenly Kings said to the Buddha:
Very difficult, very difficult!
God among Gods!
The Buddha said:

Hearing this essential sÅ«tra, the profound Dharma of the bodhisattvas, if one does not believe and enjoy it, loses it, does not recite it, and misses it for many kalpas, it cannot be encountered again.

Therefore, all of you who wish to attain it, to see the Buddha wherever you are, to hear the profound and wonderful Dharma, and quickly reach the unsurpassed true path, should diligently uphold, recite, and practice it, spread it to those who have not heard it, explain its meaning, cause them to receive the vast sÅ«tra and make people practice it day by day, and transform each other. The merit of this is difficult to fathom.

Suppose the trichiliocosm were filled with TathÄgatas, and a son or daughter of a good family were to make offerings and serve them for a hundred thousand eons, providing all necessities, and after the Buddha's parinirvÄá¹‡a, were to erect stÅ«pas for each of them, made of the seven treasures, reaching up to the twenty-fourth heaven, and make offerings of banners, canopies, music, and songs for another hundred thousand eons. Would the merit be much?
The Four Heavenly Kings said to the Buddha:
It is extremely much, with no limit.
God among Gods!
It cannot be compared.
The Buddha said:
Those who receive this samÄdhi, the ten dharmas surpassing the sun's brightness, the six pÄramitÄs, and skillful means, their merit surpasses that.
Why is it so?

Although one may serve the Buddha, it is not as good as receiving this Buddha's bequeathed sÅ«tra and following the Great Sage's instructions. All the practices of bodhisattvas are accomplished through the profound sÅ«tras, leading to the attainment of Buddhahood.
At that time, Bodhisattva MaitrÄ«pÄla said to the Buddha:
This Dharma is extremely profound!
If there are those who have faith and joy and do not slander, they will know they are protected by the Buddha;

If they hear it and are not delighted, have doubts and ridicule it, do not copy it, recite it, or chant it, and themselves not only not recite it but also stop others from studying it, the offense is immeasurable.
